summary:
Qualified physics & chemistry teacher with an academic research background as a PhD student. I have experience teaching in international schools (IB, IGCSE), grades 6-12. I am currently teaching adults in higher education.

I am developing in the field of special educational needs and disabilities (SEND), having an interest in how pedagogies in special education and educational technologies can be interfaced for an enhanced teaching and learning of Science.

projects:
[{'title': 'Online teaching and learning during COVID: Build your own DIY spectrometer!', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': 'This is an online class and activity I recorded for 2020 "Explosion Week" at Sevilla International School "San Francisco de Paula".', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Gabriele', 'last_name': 'Panarelli', 'name': None, 'headline': 'PhD | Physics Teacher & Special Education'}]}, {'title': 'WebQuest on Inclusivity in Chemistry', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': "As part of my internship at the American School of Bilbao, which was done online due to the COVID-19 pandemic, I designed a WebQuest on Inclusivity in Chemistry as a CAS experience for my Chemistry class (Y-11, IB Diploma Programme).

The goal of the WebQuest was to raise students' awareness about the importance of diversity in Science, and about the power (and responsibility!) each one of us has to actively promote inclusion and access to the curriculum for people with disabilities and/or learning disorders.

In this specific WebQuest, students were asked to think about the challenges people with dyslexia face, especially when confronted to the instructions of a laboratory practical. The students were then asked to come up with a set of schematic, graphical instructions to help their classmates with dyslexia more easily understand the steps involved in the experiments, thus facilitating their full and meaningful participation to the lab activities.

People with disabilities and/or learning disorders keep being underrepresented or outright excluded in scientific activity, especially when it comes to lab practice. Often this is due to a lack of community help to overcome various kinds of barriers. However, it's up to anyone of us to make school/work/research environments more inclusive, and it's important to keep raising awareness on this issue.", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Gabriele', 'last_name': 'Panarelli', 'name': None, 'headline': 'PhD | Physics Teacher & Special Education'}]}]
